overview: From 2025-11-01 to 2025-12-01, ethereum-optimism/optimism had 244 new PRs (145 merged), 82 new issues, and 113 active contributors.

topIssues.title: Remove IFaultDisputeGame dependency from AnchorStateRegistry
topIssues.author: ajsutton
topIssues.body:
The AnchorStateRegistry checks that the anchorStateRegistry() from the dispute game matches the AnchorStateRegistry itself via a cast to `IFaultDisputeGame`. This won't work for any game type that doesn't have a `anchorStateRegistry()` method.

https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism/blob/578622ccebb1b83210026f72fa9875097f4362ce/packages/contracts-bedrock/src/dispute/AnchorStateRegistry.sol#L199-L201

We should review if this is really necessary (we're trusting the game's `wasRespectedGameTypeWhenCreated()` method anyway so seems odd to not just require that the game was created via the DisputeGameFactory). If it is we need to add `anchorStateRegistry()` to the `IDisputeGame` interface and implement it in all game types.

topIssues.title: op-acceptance-test: add back op-reth to jovian kt-devnet
topIssues.author: wlawt
topIssues.body:
Right now op-reth doesn't have the min base fee. So this issue is created to track that once op-reth is updated then we can add back the image to the yaml file.

Context: https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism/pull/17441#discussion_r2352622905

topIssues.title: op-batcher: stay in sync with op-node rollup config
topIssues.author: joshklop
topIssues.body:
Upon startup, the op-batcher fetches the rollup config from the op-node over RPC. It never fetches the rollup config after that.

https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism/blob/40554025301e5adde90191adba6ad432e185fa50/op-batcher/batcher/service.go#L238-L253

This is problematic during hard forks when the system deposit transaction format changes: an outdated rollup config will result in an error from which the batcher cannot recover without restarting.
https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism/blob/40554025301e5adde90191adba6ad432e185fa50/op-batcher/batcher/driver.go#L310
```
failed to parse L1 info deposit tx from L2 block: data is unexpected length: 178
```

The op-batcher should stay in sync with the op-node's rollup config.

One solution is to fetch the rollup config if the above error is hit. An alternative is to for the batcher to restart itself automatically.

topIssues.title: possible bug in op-node sequencer recover mode
topIssues.author: geoknee
topIssues.body:
On a partner's testnet, recover mode was enabled on the sequencer _during normal operation_ (i.e. not after a sequencing window expiry / autoderivation situation). The following logs were then seen on verifier nodes:


```
t=2025-11-18T22:17:00+0000 lvl=info msg="decoded singular batch from channel" batch_type=SingularBatch batch_timestamp=1763488130 parent_hash=0x303a8d56bc568ee033ef69ba1135d8c1f30e472f97b9f85f1ae136956efb0cfe batch_epoch=0x1d01afb5316a7640d6b6a0fd36dc42c0a2e01b7b95bb6f701e2789be0aeff341:9656474 txs=0 compression_algo=brotli stage_origin=0x3c4778595a56b74d95e54179ea21c8c9b052f2c523d851f49f116b7f1b2a0734:9657864
t=2025-11-18T22:17:00+0000 lvl=info msg="batch exceeded sequencer time drift without adopting next origin, and next L1 origin would have been valid" origin=0x3c4778595a56b74d95e54179ea21c8c9b052f2c523d851f49f116b7f1b2a0734:9657864 epoch=0x1d01afb5316a7640d6b6a0fd36dc42c0a2e01b7b95bb6f701e2789be0aeff341:9656474 batch_type=SingularBatch batch_timestamp=1763488130 parent_hash=0x303a8d56bc568ee033ef69ba1135d8c1f30e472f97b9f85f1ae136956efb0cfe batch_epoch=0x1d01afb5316a7640d6b6a0fd36dc42c0a2e01b7b95bb6f701e2789be0aeff341:9656474 txs=0
t=2025-11-18T22:17:00+0000 lvl=warn msg="Dropping invalid singular batch, flushing channel" origin=0x3c4778595a56b74d95e54179ea21c8c9b052f2c523d851f49f116b7f1b2a0734:9657864 epoch=0x1d01afb5316a7640d6b6a0fd36dc42c0a2e01b7b95bb6f701e2789be0aeff341:9656474 batch_type=SingularBatch batch_timestamp=1763488130 parent_hash=0x303a8d56bc568ee033ef69ba1135d8c1f30e472f97b9f85f1ae136956efb0cfe batch_epoch=0x1d01afb5316a7640d6b6a0fd36dc42c0a2e01b7b95bb6f701e2789be0aeff341:9656474 txs=0
t=2025-11-18T22:17:00+0000 lvl=info msg="decoded singular batch from channel" batch_type=SingularBatch batch_timestamp=1763488130 parent_hash=0x303a8d56bc568ee033ef69ba1135d8c1f30e472f97b9f85f1ae136956efb0cfe batch_epoch=0x1d01afb5316a7640d6b6a0fd36dc42c0a2e01b7b95bb6f701e2789be0aeff341:9656474 txs=0 compression_algo=brotli stage_origin=0x3c4778595a56b74d95e54179ea21c8c9b052f2c523d851f49f116b7f1b2a0734:9657864
```

Suggesting that the sequencer violated the sequencer drift rules https://specs.optimism.io/protocol/fjord/derivation.html?highlight=sequencer%20drift#constant-maximum-sequencer-drift 

Other context:

The sequencer also logged
```
t=2025-11-18T17:19:46+0000 lvl=error msg="Error finding next L1 Origin" err="temp: failed to fetch next L1 origin: not found"
```
as a recurring pattern (but also during recover mode) .

topPRs.title: Remove majority rule
topPRs.author: miguelCyclone
topPRs.body:
**Description**
This PR replaces the previous `NewMultipleNodesClient` usage with a single-client configuration based on `NewClient()`.

**Changes**:
- Removed majority-rule logic from `cli.go` and `service,go`
- Updated to initialise a NewClient instance from the first QueryServiceURLs entry.

**Reasoning**:
- Current integration uses a duplicated URL value for QueryServiceURLs.
- The Asana ticket **(“Remove majority rule”)** requests deprecation of the multi-node client.
- NewClient() matches the desired simplified behaviour while keeping compatibility with the EspressoClient interface.

**Tests**:
- `just smoke-tests` → passed
- ` just fast-tests `→ passed
- Code builds successfully inside Nix shell
- No changes to CLI/API surface

Let me know if you want any adjustments or a different approach.

topPRs.title: feat: introduce fee splitter for revenue share
topPRs.author: 0xDiscotech
topPRs.body:
**Description**

Introduce the `FeeSplitter` predeploy as part of a new revenue-sharing feature. The goal is to make revenue sharing simpler and more modular, with configurable values and automated handling where possible.

Includes supporting contracts like `SuperchainRevSharesCalculator`, `L1Withdrawer`, and `FeesDepositor`, which act as periphery components of the system and cover the first expected use case.

This is opt-in, but will be enabled by default on fresh chains at genesis. Operators must set a chain fees recipient address on L2 for splits to work.

`FeeVaults` were updated to be more flexible with setters, while keeping backwards compatibility.

**Tests**

* All new contracts are fully unit tested.
* Genesis logic has dedicated tests, and there ar integration tests covering the full main flow.
* Invariant tests added using Foundry as fuzzer.

**Additional context**

* [specs](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/specs/pull/782)
* [design-docs](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/design-docs/pull/328)

**Metadata**

When the `FeesDepositor` contract for OP’s L1 fees is deployed, it should be linked [here](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism/issues/17505)

⚠️  **Disclaimer**: We made minimal changes to the Go files to get the checks passing and did so carefully. Go isn’t our primary expertise, so we’d appreciate extra attention from Go reviewers on these edits.

completedItems.title: Recommended a Safe fallback owner
completedItems.body:
When removing the TimelockGuard in a call to `changeOwnershipToFallback`, all scheduled or cancelled transactions at or below the Safe nonce become immediately executable. This could be catastrophic in an adversarial scenario.

To mitigat

topContributors.summary: sbvegan: Focused on critical documentation and registry updates, merging 12 PRs to support network communications and upgrades. They executed a major update to notice pages for communications in `ethereum-optimism/docs#1847` (+2155/-698 lines) and managed key details for the Jovian hard fork, including updating release information in `ethereum-optimism/docs#1852`. In addition to these direct contributions, sbvegan was an active collaborator, providing 25 code reviews. This work shows a primary focus on maintaining and improving project documentation.

devin-ai-integration: Focused on improving the quality and clarity of documentation and contract specifications for the Ethereum Optimism project. They made several impactful enhancements to the specifications, most notably by linking defined terms to their definitions in a large refactor (`specs#856`, +274/-225 lines), adding a new `SuperFaultDisputeGame` variant (`specs#852`), and cleaning up existing contract specs (`specs#853`, `specs#854`). This was complemented by a broad effort across 12 separate pull requests to fix typos and grammatical errors throughout the `ethereum-optimism/docs` repository, demonstrating a clear focus on improving overall documentation and specification quality.

ajsutton: Focused on supporting the team through collaboration this month. They contributed to project progress by providing 3 pull request reviews, which included 2 approvals. Additionally, they participated in discussions by commenting on one issue.
joshklop: No activity this month.

smartcontracts: Focused on improving CI processes and contributing to future design this month, merging a pull request to enhance upgrade tests in CI (ethereum-optimism/optimism#18133). They also authored a significant design document for OPCM v2 (ethereum-optimism/design-docs#353) and were highly engaged in supporting the team's work, providing 30 code reviews. Their contributions show a focus on development infrastructure, design, and team collaboration.

maurelian: This month, maurelian focused on development tooling and new features, merging a PR to optimize the build process in `op-deployers` (ethereum-optimism/optimism#18130). They also proposed a new `DeployFeesDepositor` script (ethereum-optimism/optimism#18223) and provided significant team support by conducting 16 code reviews. Based on their code changes, their work was primarily centered on feature development and testing.

bitwiseguy: This month, bitwiseguy focused on maintaining the deployment tooling, with their primary contribution being the support for the `op-contracts/v5.0.0-rc.2` upgrade in the `op-deployer` (ethereum-optimism/optimism#18154). They also fixed related test timeouts in the CLI runner via PR ethereum-optimism/optimism#18179. In addition to their own changes, they actively supported the team by providing 8 code reviews. This work shows a primary focus on bug fixes and testing within the deployment process.

pcw109550: Focused on node synchronization within the `ethereum-optimism/optimism` repository, proposing a significant Proof of Concept for a "Light CL" in `op-node` (optimism#18196). In support of this effort, they identified and created three issues related to node syncing and potential bugs (#18124, #18125, #18126). While their primary development work was on this open PR, they also actively supported the team by conducting 14 code reviews. Their code changes, which modified 34 files, were primarily focused on bug fixes and tests.
geoknee: Contributed by reviewing and approving one pull request.

sebastianst: Focused on significant refactoring and modularization within the `ethereum-optimism/optimism` repository to improve its core architecture. They led this effort by moving fork names into a new package (#18121) and relocating package predeploys (#18145), both substantial architectural changes. Alongside this refactoring, sebastianst also fixed a configuration loading bug in the batch decoder (#18209) and actively supported the team by providing 17 code reviews.

JosepBove: Focused on operational maintenance in the `ethereum-optimism/superchain-ops` repository, merging two PRs to update an RPC configuration and apply a bugfix for betanets (#1281, #1280). They were also an active collaborator, providing 7 reviews and 5 comments on other pull requests. Their contributions were primarily focused on bug fixes and other work, with a third of their file modifications involving documentation.
Inphi: No activity this month.

mds1: Focused on CI and deployment pipeline maintenance this month, merging 6 small PRs to address bugs and configuration issues. Their contributions included updating CLI flags for the op-deployer (optimism#18143) and renaming CI jobs to align with required checks (optimism#18139). In addition to their own fixes, mds1 was an active collaborator, providing 19 code reviews for teammates. This activity shows a primary focus on bug fixes and configuration changes to ensure system stability.

aliersh: Focused on repository maintenance and developer experience, merging three pull requests this month. Their most impactful contribution was a refactor in ethereum-optimism/optimism#18212 that removed a 157-line script, simplifying the codebase. They also improved repository organization by moving specifications in ethereum-optimism/specs#851 and enhanced CI guidance for developers in ethereum-optimism/optimism#18127. This work, along with 5 code reviews, demonstrates a focus on refactoring and bug fixes, with changes primarily affecting test files.

nonsense: Focused on improving the reliability and efficiency of the Optimism stack, merging four pull requests across multiple repositories. Their most impactful contributions included restricting the transaction mempool to trusted peers in `ethereum-optimism/op-geth#719` and executing a significant refactor of the `op-batcher` in `ethereum-optimism/optimism#18174`. In addition to their own code, they supported the team by providing 6 code reviews. Their work was primarily focused on feature enhancements and bug fixes, with changes distributed across both application code and tests.

opgitgovernance: This month, opgitgovernance focused on automated maintenance and improving test stability across repositories. They opened pull requests in `optimism` to address test flakiness (#18106, #18107) and submitted automated code generation updates to `superchain-registry` (#1137, #1138). Additionally, they generated automated metrics reports by opening and closing two issues in the `docs` repository (#1825, #1826), with their code changes primarily touching tests and configuration files.
almanax-ai: No activity this month.

Vaios0x: Focused on proposing a broad set of enhancements for the `op-node` component within the `ethereum-optimism/optimism` repository, opening 33 pull requests this month. The proposed work includes significant new features such as a retry system with exponential backoff (#18116), improved context and timeout management (#18118), and enhanced error handling (#18113). Additionally, Vaios0x submitted comprehensive architecture documentation (#18117) and numerous other documentation improvements, though none of this work has been merged.
janjakubnanista: No activity this month.

scharissis: Focused on maintenance and reliability within the acceptance testing framework this month. They merged several small PRs for chores and CI fixes, including updating a dependency version in `ethereum-optimism/optimism#18120` and correcting a CI token in `ethereum-optimism/optimism#18156`. Additionally, scharissis proactively identified and created issues to address a flaky test (`#17548`) and report unused tests (`#16273`). Their contributions centered on test and configuration file modifications.

Wazabie: This month, Wazabie's primary effort involved a significant volume of code changes (+5050/-1311 lines) across 82 commits, which is categorized as 'other work'. They merged one pull request in `ethereum-optimism/superchain-ops` to update the OPCMv500 template (#1282) and also provided one review approval. Based on the files modified, their work was heavily concentrated on improving tests and documentation.

axelKingsley: Focused on developing the `op-supernode` component, merging a key feature PR in ethereum-optimism/optimism (#18141) to implement runnable and RPC activities with a heartbeat example. They continued this effort with three additional open PRs to expand `op-supernode` functionality, including a Superroot API and P2P capabilities. In addition to their implementation work, they supported the team by providing 5 code reviews. Axel's code contributions this month were primarily focused on new feature work, with smaller efforts dedicated to bugfixes and documentation.
serpixel: No activity this month.

ZakAyesh: Focused on improving documentation for the Optimism ecosystem, merging two pull requests in `ethereum-optimism/docs`. They added new configuration sections for `minBaseFee` and `DA Footprint` (docs#1830) and authored a new guide on setting the minimum base fee (docs#1849). In addition to this documentation work, ZakAyesh contributed 4 code reviews and has an open pull request to add a key handback task in `superchain-ops` (#1284).

teddyknox: This month, teddyknox's primary contribution was merging a pull request in `ethereum-optimism/optimism` to "Debounce FCU Update" (#18234). In addition to this code change, they engaged in project discussions by commenting on 2 issues and 3 pull requests. Their activity was focused on code modifications within the optimism repository.
falcorocks: Supported the team through code review, approving 2 pull requests this month.

alcueca: This month, alcueca focused on security hardening by addressing audit findings for Safer Safes in the `ethereum-optimism/optimism` repository.
